item.title: County-Level Climate Risk Index for Banking System Vulnerability
item.description:
Matched meteorological station data (temperature, precipitation, wind speed, SPEI) from year 2002-2022 to Chinese county boundaries within a set threshold

Utilized Inverse Distance Weighting (IDW) to calculate daily maximum and minimum temperatures, 20h-20h cumulative precipitation, maximum wind speed, and Standardized Precipitation Evapotranspiration Index (SPEI) for each county using ArcGIS, R, and Python

Assigned weights to different climate factors (# of consecutive extreme heat days, # of consecutive extreme cold days, # of rainstorm days, SPEI levels, # of tropical storm days) using Kolmogorovâ€“Arnold Networks (KAN) and empirical methods to construct a county-level climate risk index

Assessed the vulnerability of banks to climate risks across different regions by evaluating their exposure, sensitivity, and adaptive capacity, following the framework established by the IPCC

item.title: Spillover Effects of Climate Physical Risk on Supply-chain Networks
item.description:
Investigated the climate risk impact on suppliers and customers and developed effective risk management strategies by constructing the C-Vine-Copula model

Fit the marginal distributions of climate variables and explored the tail dependence between climate risk factors affecting suppliers and the financial performance of customers in the supply-chain networks

Utilized the first-order network coupling and second-order network coupling index to analyze the impact of climate risk on the embeddedness of supply-chain networks, finding extreme high and low temperatures can increase the dispersion of customers within the supply-chain networks
